title: 115_s361
content: The Act may be cited as the "Expatriate Terrorist Act" and addresses loss of nationality due to support of terrorism. Section 349(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to specify acts that can result in loss of U.S. nationality, such as obtaining naturalization in a foreign state, pledging allegiance to a foreign state or terrorist organization, or serving in a foreign armed force. Section 349(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to specify acts that can result in loss of U.S. nationality, such as serving in a foreign armed force engaged in hostilities against the United States or accepting a position under a foreign government after acquiring their nationality. The Immigration and Nationality Act specifies acts that can lead to loss of U.S. nationality, including taking an oath of allegiance to a foreign state or renouncing U.S. nationality before a diplomatic officer. The Immigration and Nationality Act outlines actions that can result in loss of U.S. nationality, such as committing treason or providing material support to enemies of the United States. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for loss of U.S. nationality for actions like treason or providing support to foreign terrorist organizations engaged in hostilities against the United States. The Passport Act of 1926 is amended to allow for the revocation or denial of passports and passport cards to individuals who are members of foreign terrorist organizations. The Secretary of State is prohibited from issuing passports to individuals serving in foreign terrorist organizations and deemed a threat to national security. Passports issued to such individuals must be revoked. Any person denied a passport under this section has the right to review. The Secretary of State can deny issuance, revoke, or restrict passports, but individuals have the right to request a due process hearing within 60 days. A national security waiver allows the Secretary to issue or refuse to revoke passports if it is in the interest of the United States. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENT. Amends Section 351(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act by including subsection (8) in addition to subsections (3) and (5).
